docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1982 Joanne B. Booth, a 45-year-old divorcee, moved to Wausau, Wis., and started looking for a job. ''No one would hire me,'' said Mrs. Booth, who had worked as a waitress in Minnesota. ''My self- confidence fell to zero because I felt that I had nothing to offer an employer.'' One day she read an advertisement in a local newspaper announcing a Federal retraining program for women who were unemployed or on welfare. The six-week course, which was sponsored by the Women's Community of Wausau with funds from the Job Training Partnership Act, taught Mrs. Booth how to assess her skills, write a resume and conduct herself in an interview. Best of all, the center put her in touch with the Marathon County Health Department, which hired her as a receptionist.

headline.main: RETRAINING'S COME A LONG WAY, BABY
